Title: Leonardo DiCaprio shocks fans with ‚ÄòTitanic' confession
Description:
Leonardo DiCaprio revealed he has never rewatched his 1997 film ‚ÄúTitanic.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I haven't seen it in forever.‚Äù  DiCaprio, 51, responded when asked by Jennifer Lawrence during Variety and CNN's Actors on Actors conversation Wednesday.

‚ÄúOh, you should. I bet you could watch it as a movie now, it's so good!‚Äù Lawrence, 35, pushed back. 

Advertisement

DiCaprio went on to explain that he doesn't ‚Äúreally watch my films,‚Äù before admitting to watching ‚Äúsome.‚Äù 

Advertisement

He then asked the ‚ÄúHunger Games‚Äù actress if she watches some of the films from her catalog. 

‚ÄúNo. I've never made something like ‚ÄòTitanic.' If I did I would watch it,‚Äù she answered with a short laugh.

However, when asked about the last time she watched one of her films, the Oscar winner admitted that she drunkenly rewatched her 2013 film, ‚ÄúAmerican Hustle.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was like, ‚ÄòI wonder if I'm good at acting?' I put it on, and I don't remember what the answer is.‚Äù

Advertisement


							Start your day with Page Six Daily.						




						Please provide a valid email.					



				By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.			


					Want celebrity news as it breaks?				

Advertisement

Elsewhere in their conversation, Lawrence also admitted to another funny on-set happening involving ambien.

At one point, she revealed that she accidentally took the sleep aid before heading to work that morning which resulted in her ‚Äúhallucinating‚Äù during a key scene. 

‚ÄúIt was a dance scene with Phillip Seymour-Hoffman on the second ‚ÄòHunger Games' movie and I was hallucinating,‚Äù she said. 

The incident resulted in the actress struggling with ‚Äúthe memorization‚Äù part of her brain as she tried to remember her lines.

‚ÄúElizabeth Banks got really annoyed with me because maybe, she didn't know that I was on an Ambien. But I kept asking the director, ‚ÄòWait, and what does this mean?'‚Äù she recalled. 

Advertisement

Lawrence and DiCaprio previously starred alongside each other in the 2021 Netflix film ‚ÄúDon't Look Up.‚Äù

The two actors are reportedly set to reunite for Martin Scorsese's horror film, ‚ÄúWhat Happens at Night,‚Äù per the Hollywood Reporter.

Title: Heartbroken Tara Reid speaks out after police close investigation into her drugging claim: Everyone's ‚Äòtwisting reality'
Description:
Tara Reid is speaking out after police closed down the investigation into her claims she was drugged at a bar in Chicago last month. 

The entire ordeal is ‚Äútruly heartbreaking,‚Äù the ‚ÄúAmerican Pie‚Äù actress's representative shared with Page Six on Wednesday.

‚ÄúAll of the bullying I have been subjected to since and everyone twisting reality without the facts they weren't even there to witness is truly affecting my mental health, and I need it to stop,‚Äù she said.

Advertisement

‚ÄúThey are making it seem like I chugged all this wine at once and ended up on a stretcher, but after reviewing the footage that is not what happened at all,‚Äù she explained.

Advertisement

‚ÄúIn fact I witnessed in the footage when I arrived back from smoking with the person I only took one sip of wine in over 30 minutes and when the bartender asked me if I wanted another drink I signalled no because I still had a drink I didn't barely touch,‚Äù she claimed.

Reid also told the Daily Mail on Wednesday that 33 minutes of footage of the Nov. 23 incident ‚Äî during which she was seen in a wheelchair in a hotel lobby before being taken out on a stretcher ‚Äî was unaccounted for.

A Rosemont, Ill., police spokesperson told People on Wednesday that the case had been closed on Dec. 11, explaining that ‚Äúno other evidence‚Äù had been found to support Reid's claim.

‚ÄúWe don't want to say what she's claiming is false,‚Äù the spokesperson said, adding that there were stretches of time ‚Äúnot seen‚Äù on the surveillance video. 

Advertisement

They noted that they could only investigate the footage they had access to, which they felt did not provide proof of an alleged drugging. ‚ÄúThat's all we can do,‚Äù the spokesperson said. 

A rep for Reid did not immediately return Page Six's request for further comment. 

Advertisement

The actress, 50, told Page Six on Dec. 8 that she felt ‚Äújudged‚Äù as footage of the incident proliferated in the media. 

‚ÄúI've been honest about the fact that I don't remember anything after my first drink,‚Äù she told us. 

‚ÄúAll I said was that I felt something was wrong and that I felt I may have been drugged, because I have no other explanation for why I woke up in a hospital gown with no memory of how I got there.‚Äù

She added that it ‚Äúhas been incredibly painful‚Äù to see people ‚Äútwist [her] words and attack [her]‚Äù for not remembering details of what allegedly transpired. 

‚ÄúI feel bullied and judged for something I cannot recall. I'm trying to heal, but the public scrutiny is making that very difficult, and I've been afraid to even leave my house,‚Äù she said. 

‚ÄúNo one ends up in the hospital for around 11 hours from drinking wine alone. I hadn't taken any medication that day, and I know something wasn't right.‚Äù

Advertisement


							Start your day with Page Six Daily.						




						Please provide a valid email.					



				By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.			


					Want celebrity news as it breaks?				

The ‚ÄúSharknado‚Äù star first spoke out in November about an alleged drugging after footage showed her being removed from a Chicago hotel bar on a stretcher.

Advertisement

The ‚ÄúVan Wilder‚Äù actress told Page Six at the time that she checked into her room and then headed to the bar, where she encountered YouTubers in the lobby. 

She claimed one of them later joined her for a cigarette, and that when she returned to the bar, her drink was covered by a napkin ‚Äî which she didn't do, she explained to TMZ.

Reid alleged she woke up in a hospital eight hours later, claiming doctors informed her she'd been drugged.

Advertisement

She filed a police report obtained by Page Six in November hat stated she was ‚Äúwilling to prosecute‚Äù ‚Äî however, initial surveillance findings failed to reveal evidence of misconduct, the Rosemont Public Safety Department said on Dec. 3. 

‚ÄúWhile video surveillance showed Tara Reid at the hotel bar, at no time did video show anyone tampering with or adding something to her drink,‚Äù they said in a statement earlier this month. 

Advertisement

‚ÄúWe can confirm that a bartender covered her drink when she left the bar which is standard practice for bartenders to do.‚Äù

The message concluded by stating that authorities found ‚Äúno criminal act that has been committed‚Äù in the case.

Title: Prince Harry hits the polo field in Aspen ahead of holiday trip with Meghan Markle
Description:
Prince Harry is hitting the polo field in Aspen, Colo. ahead of his future holiday plans with Meghan Markle and their family. 

Photos showed the Duke of Sussex, 41, playing a friendly game of polo with pals on Wednesday in what appears to be a sporty break for the royal.

He appeared lively as he showed off his well-practiced skills on top of a horse in his light blue Aspen Valley team polo jersey and white pants. He finished off his look with a pair of dark shades and the rest of his athletic gear. 

Advertisement

The prince previously made an appearance in the Colorado hot spot for a charity polo match in 2021 following the birth of his daughter, Princess Lilibet, now 4.

Advertisement

Hours before his polo photos surfaced, an additional set of photos were posted showing Harry skiing with his friend Nacho Figueras.

‚ÄúPrince Harry was with Nacho for about four hours on the mountains. The pair spent the day skiing and enjoyed lunch together at one of the restaurants at the resort,‚Äù a source told Hello! Magazine.

‚ÄúHarry seemed happy and was also joined by a number of male friends on the slopes.‚Äù

Advertisement

According to the outlet, neither Markle, 44, nor their children made the trip with him. 


							Start your day with Page Six Daily.						




						Please provide a valid email.					



				By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.			


					Want celebrity news as it breaks?				

Advertisement

However, as Page Six previously reported earlier this week, the royals are expected to still celebrate the Christmas holiday at home in Montecito, Calif., alongside their kids and Markle's mom, Doria Ragland.

But the parents have reportedly made plans to jet away with friends shortly after for a glamorous New Year's vacation out of the country.

The holiday travels come as the ‚ÄúWith Love, Meghan‚Äù star faces scrutiny for allegedly not showing up to support her ailing father, Thomas Markle, shortly after he underwent emergency surgery for a dangerous blood clot and had his leg amputated as a result.

While a rep for the royal previously claimed that the Duchess of Sussex had, in fact, reached out to her father, Thomas alleged that he had not received any correspondence from his daughter. 

‚ÄúI don't want to die estranged from Meghan. I want to meet my grandkids. It might be nice to meet her husband too,‚Äù Thomas told the Daily Mail at the time. 

Advertisement

In the most recent update, the Sussex rep had since told Page Six that Markle finally managed to get a letter to her father.

‚ÄúIt has been exceedingly difficult for the duchess to contact her father privately, despite her efforts over the past several days,‚Äù said the rep. ‚ÄúWith the support of reliable and trusted contacts, her correspondence is now safely in his hands.‚Äù

Title: Ex-Astronomer HR exec Kristin Cabot finally breaks silence on Coldplay kiss cam scandal: ‚ÄòBad decision'
Description:
Kristin Cabot has finally broken her silence after she and her former boss Andy Byron went viral for getting caught canoodling on the kiss cam at a Coldplay concert over the summer.

Cabot, 53, debated speaking publicly about the scandal but eventually agreed to do an interview with the New York Times for an article published Thursday.

She insisted to the newspaper that she was not in a sexual relationship with Byron, claiming that before that night, they had never even kissed.

Advertisement

‚ÄúI made a bad decision and had a couple of High Noons and danced and acted inappropriately with my boss,‚Äù she explained, making sure to note that ‚Äúit's not nothing.‚Äù

Advertisement

However, she feels she ‚Äútook accountability‚Äù and ‚Äúgave up [her] career‚Äù for the ordeal.

‚ÄúThat's the price I chose to pay,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI want my kids to know that you can make mistakes, and you can really screw up, but you don't have to be threatened to be killed for them.‚Äù

Cabot said she and Byron ‚Äúclicked, stylistically,‚Äù when she interviewed to work for Astronomer in the summer of 2024. Soon after she was hired that November, she and Byron started speaking every day, sometimes three times a day.

In the spring, Cabot, the then-head of HR, claimed she and Byron, the then-CEO, bonded over both ‚Äúgoing through‚Äù separations, which ‚Äúsort of strengthened [their] connection.‚Äù

Advertisement

She quickly developed ‚Äúbig feelings‚Äù for him and started fantasizing about the romantic possibilities but knew she couldn't ‚Äúget too carried away‚Äù given their professional dynamic.

She told the Times that by the time she invited Byron to the Boston Coldplay concert in July as her plus-one, she had a full-blown ‚Äúcrush.‚Äù However, it wasn't a proper date, as they were with a group of her close friends.

Advertisement

Cabot admitted that she and Byron each had a couple of tequila cocktails, and as the concert went on, they began to look like a couple. Byron was dancing behind Cabot when she took his hands and wrapped his arms around her, she said.

That's when the camera panned to the pair, and they were shown on the jumbotron in an intimate embrace.

‚ÄúWhoa, look at these two,‚Äù frontman Chris Martin exclaimed into the mic.

However, once the duo noticed they were on the big screen, Byron let out a ‚Äúf‚Äìking hell, it's me‚Äù and immediately ducked out of view, while Cabot, who acknowledged that ‚Äúthis is awkward,‚Äù hid her face in embarrassment.

‚ÄúEither they're having an affair, or they're just very shy,‚Äù Martin joked as the audience erupted in laughter, with videos of the moment quickly spreading like wildfire online.


							Start your day with Page Six Daily.						




						Please provide a valid email.					



				By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.			


					Want celebrity news as it breaks?				

Advertisement

‚ÄúI was so embarrassed and so horrified,‚Äù Cabot told the Times. ‚ÄúI'm the head of HR, and he's the CEO. It's, like, so clich√© and so bad.‚Äù

She said she and Byron immediately drafted up an email to Astronomer's Board of Directors, but by the time they hit ‚Äúsend,‚Äù the footage was everywhere.

The board then launched an investigation into the matter, which resulted in both Byron and Cabot ‚Äî who were both technically married at the time ‚Äî being placed on leave.

The former resigned the next day, while his direct report followed suit less than a week later, though she claimed to the Times that the board had actually asked her to return to her role.

Advertisement

Cabot's family and friends ‚Äî those who didn't jump ship amid the subsequent public scrutiny and consistent death threats ‚Äî were devastated. She said her children became ‚Äúafraid that [she] was going to die and they were going to die.‚Äù

Advertisement

In early September, Cabot's estranged husband, CEO of Privateer Rum Andrew Cabot, revealed they ‚Äúwere privately and amicably separated several weeks before the Coldplay concert.‚Äù

She filed for divorce in mid-August.

It's unclear where Byron and his wife, Megan Kerrigan, stand, but she did instantly remove her married name from her Facebook page before deleting her account altogether.

Cabot said she and Byron were in touch amid the fallout but eventually agreed that ‚Äúspeaking with each other was going to make it too hard for everyone to move on and heal.‚Äù

Byron declined to comment on the article.

Title: Inside Rob Reiner's son Nick's ‚Äòdrained' and ‚Äòabnormal' behavior days before parents' double murder
Description:
Rob Reiner's son Nick Reiner displayed ‚Äúabnormal‚Äù and ‚Äúdrained‚Äù behavior days before he was charged with murder for stabbing his parents to death.

An employee who works at Sinclair Gas station in the Brentwood area of California told TMZ that Nick looked tired and was unusually standoffish about two weeks ago. 

The worker said Nick, who is usually social and friendly at the gas station, bought a pack of cigarettes and did not appear to be under the influence of drugs or alcohol.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The outlet reported that the Reiners were frequent customers, with one employee saying he had known Nick for 15 years.

As Page Six previously reported, Rob, 78, and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, 70, were found dead in their Brentwood home on Sunday.

Nick was arrested and charged with two counts of first-degree murder. He is currently being held without bail at the Twin Towers Correctional Facility in LA.

Advertisement


							Start your day with Page Six Daily.						




						Please provide a valid email.					



				By clicking above you agree to the Terms of Use and Privacy Policy.			


					Want celebrity news as it breaks?				

The Post obtained surveillance video of Nick calmly walking past the Sinclair Gas station, which was blocks away from his parents' home, just hours before Rob and Michele were killed.

Advertisement

The ‚ÄúBeing Charlie‚Äù writer had a history of violent outbursts and drug addiction.

The night before the killings, a source confirmed to The Post that Nick ‚Äúfreaked out‚Äù and had a massive blow-up with his parents at Conan O'Brien's Christmas party. 

On Wednesday, the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner released the couple's official cause of death. The filmmaker and the actress died from ‚Äúmultiple sharp force injuries‚Äù and their passing was listed as a homicide.

That same day, Rob and Michele's kids, Romy, 28, and Jake, 34, released a statement about the ‚Äúhorrific‚Äù murder of their parents.

‚ÄúWords cannot even begin to describe the unimaginable pain we are experiencing every moment of the day,‚Äù they told Page Six.

Advertisement

‚ÄúThe horrific and devastating loss of our parents, Rob and Michele Reiner, is something that no one should ever experience,‚Äù the siblings added.

‚ÄúThey weren't just our parents; they were our best friends. We are grateful for the outpouring of condolences, kindness, and support we have received not only from family and friends but people from all walks of life.‚Äù 

Romy and Jake concluded their statement by asking for ‚Äúrespect and privacy‚Äù as they navigate this difficult time. They did not mention their brother, Nick.

Title: Apple TV to defrost more Monarch monsters for Wyatt Russell-led spinoff series
Description:
When a monarch butterfly flaps its wings, Apple TV green-lights 16 new shows. While most might never be seen or heard from again [did anyone else know that Megan Thee Stallion and Psy hosted a show called KPOPPED together?], others are attached to big, expensive IP and therefore deserve your undivided attention. One of those is Monarch: Legacy Of Monsters, a spin-off of 2014's Godzilla, a franchise-launcher for a franchise that didn't start clicking until King Kong got involved. Debuting in 2023, Monarch stars Wyatt and Kurt Russell, who share the role of Lee Shaw across two timelines as they hunt the Titans, the race of supermonsters better known to the rest of the world as Kaiju. It's all part of the Monsterverse, and today, Apple announced that the universe is expanding enough for Wyatt Russell to star in his own spin-off.

Here's the synopsis for the still untitled series: ‚ÄúStarring and executive produced by Wyatt Russell, the spinoff series will follow the story of Colonel Lee Shaw, an American operative who in 1984 went on a secret mission behind enemy lines in an attempt to stop the Soviets from unleashing a horrific new Titan big enough to destroy the U.S. and turn the tide of the Cold War.‚Äù

The series will be showrun by Emmy-nominated screenwriter Joby Harold. Harold was previously nominated for Outstanding Limited or Anthology Series for Obi-Wan Kenobi, which he created, produced, and wrote. His other screenwriting credits include The Flash, Transformers: Rise Of The Beasts, and King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword.

There's no word on when the show will be released or whether Godzilla will make guest appearances, but more monsters are on the way. The second season of the mainline Monarch series hits Apple TV on February 27, 2026.

Title: FCC Chair says the FCC is not independent
Description:
FCC Chair Brendan Carr doesn't care what the website says; the FCC is not an independent agency. At least that's what he told Congress today. Testifying before the Senate's commerce, science, and transportation agency, Carr, using the overworked semantics that are the backbone of Project 2025 legislation, declared the FCC ‚Äúis not an independent agency, formally speaking.‚Äù

During a surprising exchange, Senator Ben Ray Luj√°n of New Mexico, who didn't even get to his ‚Äúgotcha question,‚Äù asked whether the FCC was independent because the website says it's independent. Still, after Carr attempted to give a lengthy answer about how ‚Äúthere's a test in the law‚Äù regarding how we've all been misinterpreting the role of the FCC for the last century, Luj√°n said, ‚ÄúIt's yes or no, Brendan! On your website, it simply says, man, ‚Äòthe FCC is independent.' This isn't a trick question.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe FCC is not,‚Äù Carr responded. He continued to say that [eye roll] [jerkoff hand motion] the ‚Äúsin qua non of independence would be removable by the president.‚Äù

‚ÄúJust so you know, Brendan, on your website it just simply says, man, the FCC's independent,‚Äù Luj√°n said. It wouldn't be for long. Before the exchange, the FCC's website described the commission as ‚Äúan independent U.S. government agency overseen by Congress.‚Äù However, after the exchange, the site was updated to remove the word ‚Äúindependent.‚Äù The Congress.gov website, however, has not been updated.

KIM: Is Trump your boss?

CARR: The president designated chair of the FCC

K: So he's your boss

C: Look‚Äì

K: You swore an oath. Does it have the word ‚Äòpresident' in it?

C: I'm not tracking

K: Do you remember the oath?

C: Sir‚Äì

K: What are you protecting?

C: In this job‚Äì

K: The Constitution

[image or embed]

‚Äî Aaron Rupar (@atrupar.com) December 17, 2025 at 9:17 AM

Title: Kerry Washington, Elisabeth Moss, and Kate Mara link up in first look at Imperfect Women
Description:
It makes a certain sense that Kerry Washington and Elisabeth Moss would end up in the same series together. They're two titans of 2010s TV who've also both dabbled in limited series since the ends of Scandal and Mad Men. (Of course, Moss did all of The Handmaid's Tale since then, too.) Apparently, they agree; the two both executive produce Imperfect Women, a new eight-episode series coming to Apple TV early next year. They're also bringing Kate Mara (Friendship, American Horror Story) with them. 

Here's the synopsis for Imperfect Women: 

Based on Araminta Hall's novel of the same name, ‚ÄúImperfect Women‚Äù examines a crime that shatters the lives of a decades-long friendship of three women. The unconventional thriller explores guilt and retribution, love and betrayal, and the compromises we make that alter our lives irrevocably. As the investigation unravels, so does the truth about how even the closest friendships may not be what they seem.

Imperfect Women is created and showrun by Annie Weisman, who previously showran Physical at Apple TV and produced some of Desperate Housewives and Suburgatory on ABC. The ensemble cast of the series include names such as Leslie Odom Jr., Joel Kinnaman, Corey Stoll, and Sheryl Lee Ralph. Imperfect Women premieres on March 18 with two episodes; new episodes will premiere weekly after that. You can check out a first-look image below.

Title: Jennifer Lawrence & Leonardo DiCaprio Bond Over Their ‚ÄòBad Habits' While Filming Movies
Description:
Jennifer Lawrence and Leonardo DiCaprio discussed what they perceived as their bad habits during a sit-down for Variety's ‚ÄúActors on Actors.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think I shoot out a lot of ideas, sometimes unnecessarily,‚Äù DiCaprio said. He continued, ‚ÄúIt's kind of like a shotgun spray of anything that comes to mind, and a lot of that may waste time for the focus of what we already know.‚Äù

Lawrence answered, ‚ÄúThat sounds helpful. Because if it's not useful, then you just move on.‚Äù 

‚ÄúWell, sometimes maybe it steers away from what is obvious,‚Äù DiCaprio answered. However, Lawrence argued that his ideas might sometimes, so she thought his ‚Äúbad habit‚Äù was a good thing.  

As for Lawrence, she said, ‚ÄúMy bad habit is that I am so good at letting go at the end of the day, that I don't think about the next day.‚Äù

She explained that while getting ready in hair and makeup, she has to scramble to learn her lines, which affects her acting in front of the cameras.

‚ÄúIt makes me not go crazy, but the next morning is hell,‚Äù the ‚ÄúSilver Linings Playbook‚Äù star quipped.

Lawrence shared in the Variety talk that while filming ‚ÄúSilver Linings Playbook,‚Äù she had to memorize a bunch of sports stats, which were difficult to remember.

‚ÄúIt's just numbers and sports, which I don't care about ‚Ä¶ but it turned out great,‚Äù she recalled.

The mom of two then said, ‚ÄúI nailed it on the first take, and then I [expletive] up every single other take until we finally moved on.‚Äù

DiCaprio lamented about not being able to say the tongue twister, ‚ÄúSpruce Goose,‚Äù while filming ‚ÄúThe Aviator,‚Äù and told Lawrence, ‚ÄúI couldn't, literally couldn't say the words.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt's humiliating, and it's like going to school with your underwear on,‚Äù the ‚ÄúTitanic‚Äù actor admitted.

Lawrence and DiCaprio starred in ‚ÄúDon't Look Up‚Äù together, and they're reuniting for an upcoming Martin Scorsese film called ‚ÄúWhat Happens at Night,‚Äù per Deadline.

Based on the novel by Peter Cameron, the haunting thriller centers around a couple who make a trip to Europe in hopes of adopting a baby. 

The two stay at a strange hotel full of unusual characters, and they have to navigate being in a foreign environment while navigating their struggling marriage.

According to Netflix, ‚ÄúWhat Happens at Night‚Äù is set to start filming in January 2026.

Title: Timoth√©e Chalamet Twins with Surprise Date at ‚ÄòMarty Supreme' Premiere
Description:
Timoth√©e Chalamet arrived at the New York City premiere for his upcoming ‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù with a surprise date‚Äìhis mother, Nicole Flender. The mom-and-son duo rocked matching bright orange hues, continuing the color palette that has defined the ‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù press tour. 

Chalamet, 29, wore a double-breasted suit designed by Haider Ackermann for Tom Ford. He paired the ensemble with a matching orange scarf and watch as well as a Cartier necklace. Flender posed alongside her son, wearing a halter neck gown in ‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù orange and carrying a gold purse. 

Chalamet also wore an all-orange outfit at the Los Angeles premiere of ‚ÄúMarty Supreme,‚Äù where he twinned in nearly head-to-toe Chrome Hearts with his girlfriend, Kylie Jenner. The reality television star and cosmetics mogul wore a bright orange gown by the brand. Chalamet opted for an orange Chrome Hearts leather suit and a pair of Timberlands. Jenner paired her stunning attire with a massive cross necklace while Chalamet's accessory of choice was a custom bag shaped like a ping-pong paddle. 

The outing marked the couple's second red carpet appearance since their debut in May. 

Film premieres aren't the only place Chalamet is showing up in the neon orange. 

A ‚Äúleaked Zoom call‚Äù posted to YouTube by A24 reveals a meeting between Chalamet and a marketing team where the orange motif was born. In the video, Chalamet talks with the group about great movie marketing campaigns, eventually turning the conversation to ‚ÄúBarbie‚Äù and its association with the color pink.

‚ÄúEverywhere I stepped, I would be inundated with pink. What would the same be for ‚ÄòMarty Supreme'?‚Äù he asks. The group agreed on orange because Chalamet's character, Marty Mauser, uses an orange ping-pong ball.

‚ÄúHow do we not just cop [sic] the vibe of ‚ÄòBarbie'? Hardcore orange,‚Äù Chalamet answers his own question before pulling up a PNG of the color that would come to define the ‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù press campaign. The actor also showed edited photos of landmarks like the Statue of Liberty and the Eiffel Tower painted in the bright hue.  

Chalamet has since been rocking ‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù orange at premieres, press conferences and in social media posts. He's also sported a now-coveted windbreaker that fans are scrambling to get their hands on. Chalamet has gifted various versions of the jacket, on which ‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù is written above three stars, to fellow celebrities like Frank Ocean, Kid Cudi and even Tom Brady.

On December 16, the Empire State Building joined the trend, lighting up in bright orange as members of the ‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù cast, and director Josh Safdie, posed at the top of the building. 

‚ÄúMarty Supreme‚Äù arrives in theaters on December 25.

Title: Dick Van Dyke's Wife Opens Up About Rob Reiner & His Wife in Heartfelt Reveal
Description:
The late director and actor Rob Reiner spoke with deep affection about Dick Van Dyke and Mel Brooks just months before his death on December 14. During a September 2025 appearance on Ted Danson's podcast, ‚ÄúWhere Everybody Knows Your Name,‚Äù Reiner reflected on the lasting genius of his father Carl Reiner's longtime collaborators and the comedy legacy that helped shape his own life and career.

During the podcast conversation, Reiner noted that his father, Carl Reiner, who died in 2020 at age 98, created ‚ÄúThe Dick Van Dyke Show,‚Äù which starred Van Dyke and ran for five seasons through 1966.

Reiner said Van Dyke, who turned 100 on December 13, remained as sharp as ever. He also pointed out that Brooks, Carl's longtime comedy partner, turned 99 on June 28, 2025.

‚Äú[Van Dyke] is 100 this year. And Mel Brooks is 99 this year and, you know, these guys are still incredible,‚Äù Reiner said while speaking with Danson.

Reiner also spoke fondly about Carl Reiner and Brooks' legendary sketch ‚ÄúThe 2000 Year Old Man,‚Äù which appeared on their comedy albums ‚Äú2000 Years with Carl Reiner and Mel Brooks‚Äù in 1960 and ‚Äú2000 and One Years with Carl Reiner and Mel Brooks‚Äù in 1961.

‚ÄúIf you listen to those albums, they're the most brilliant comedy albums ever done,‚Äù Reiner said. ‚ÄúAnd as a kid, I used to come home and listen to it every day. I would listen to it, and I would know whether or not I could be friends with somebody if they got that.‚Äù

The albums, he explained, helped shape his sense of humor and his understanding of comedy as a shared language.

In a separate March 2023 interview on ‚ÄúThe Howard Stern Show,‚Äù Reiner recalled visiting his father on the set of ‚ÄúThe Dick Van Dyke Show‚Äù during his teenage years.

He said watching Carl write dozens of scripts on his own left him both inspired and overwhelmed. At the time, he wondered if he could ever match that level of discipline and creative output.

Reiner also shared a moment that stayed with him for life. As a teenager, he once pitched a joke to Carl and Brooks for a performance on ‚ÄúThe Ed Sullivan Show.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had this joke and they actually used it. That was like the greatest thrill,‚Äù Reiner said.

After the tragic passing of Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, Dick Van Dyke's wife, Arlene Silver, spoke publicly about the loss in a December 15 Instagram video, according to People.

Silver reflected on the emotional whiplash of celebrating Van Dyke's 100th birthday while learning of the Reiners' deaths during the same weekend.

‚ÄúSuch a weird, wonderful, awful weekend. I can't talk about this horrible thing‚Ä¶ I mean, Dick's birthday was so amazing, so over-the-top beautiful, and then this. I was relieved and happy, and then this happened yesterday,‚Äù Silver said.

She also spoke about the deep bond between the two couples.

‚ÄúAnd then Rob and Carl [Reiner] were the first people I ever met with Dick. Rob and Michele were always together, like Dick and I. And I always felt part of the Reiner family; they always treated me like part of their family. And this is just unbelievable,‚Äù she said.

People reported that the Reiners' 32-year-old son, Nick, was arrested and charged with first-degree murder following his parents' deaths.

Title: Rob Reiner and Wife Michele Case Update
Description:
Legendary actor Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele, were tragically killed in their home on Sunday, Dec. 14, and the medical examiner has now released the cause of death three days after their passing. 

The two died from ‚Äúmultiple sharp force injuries,‚Äù according to the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner. They also determined the manner of death to be ‚Äúhomicide.‚Äù

This comes after the couple's son, Nick Reiner, faces murder charges in the deaths of his parents and appeared in court on Wednesday, Dec. 17, having arrived in‚Äù a blue sleeveless vest and shackles, was seated behind glass in court and stared blankly as his lawyer, Alan Jackson, declined to enter a plea for his client,‚Äù according to PEOPLE.

The arraignment has been pushed back to January 7, according to the outlet.

Rob and Michele's other children, Romy and Jake, also released a statement about their parents passing. 

‚ÄúWords cannot even begin to describe the unimaginable pain we are experiencing every moment of the day. The horrific and devastating loss of our parents, Rob and Michele Reiner, is something that no one should ever experience. They weren't just our parents; they were our best friends,‚Äù the family said in a statement to TMZ on December 17. ‚ÄúWe are grateful for the outpouring of condolences, kindness, and support we have received not only from family and friends but people from all walks of life.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe now ask for respect and privacy, for speculation to be tempered with compassion and humanity, and for our parents to be remembered for the incredible lives they lived and the love they gave.‚Äù

During an appearance on a podcast in 2016, Nick admitted that it was hard for him while growing up as he had a famous father and grandfather. Feeling in the shadow of the two is what led to him abusing drugs, he explained. 

‚ÄúI had no identity, and I had no passions,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd I think the reason I had no identity was because I have a famous dad and a famous grandpa, and that fame sort of informs who you are. So I wanted to edge out my own identity with a more rebellious, angry, drug-addicted sort of persona.‚Äù

Douglas Shaffer, who was the producer of the film ‚ÄòBeing Charlie,' which was directed by Rob and was co-written by Nick, opened up about working on the film with the duo as well as his reaction to this news. 

‚ÄúIt was just a good experience for everybody involved,‚Äù Shaffer told Page Six. ‚ÄúAnd so that's why when all this stuff came up, it was just complete and total shock.‚Äù

‚ÄúNick‚Ä¶ I thought the demons were like exorcised,‚Äù Shaffer continued. ‚ÄúAfter the movie, I felt like, ‚ÄòOkay, he's on the up and up. This is good. He's doing good.' I had no idea these other issues were happening. So it was a shock. I mean, I thought it was a home invasion at first when I heard. I had no idea.‚Äù

You keep talking about his 3 kids.  Rob adopted a daughter from Penny Marshall.  Her mother died several years ago.  She only had her father left.  You keep talking about his 3 kids  where is Tracy Reiner his 4th.  Her father was  murdered . Rob was her dad  Show respect for her also.  What a disrespectful slap in the face for Tracy.  He chose to adopt her and she deserves respect because that was her legal father  She never had brothers and sister   She was an only child  They were her half siblings.

Utterly pathetic and disgusting that his own son would inflict this pain on his parents and family, what satisfaction did he receive by harming his parents. That A BIG SIN in Gods eyes and I hope he rots in jail. I hope they make him suffer the way his parents suffered. No mercy for he gave his parents any mercy

No parent should see the child they brought into the world turn their rage into an attack like this.  None of us can imagine this horror.  No one knows what happened day in and day out behind those closed doors.
Rob's political views were very hateful against Trump.  He didn't miss an opportunity to spew.  He even commented on his disappointment that Trump's life was spared when he turned his head.  For this I don't respect Rob but for the pain and horror of this tragedy, I send my prayers.

Title: ‚ÄòDreams' Trailer: Jessica Chastain's Affair with an Illegal Immigrant Implodes in Michel Franco's Dangerous Romance
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Jessica Chastain‚Äòs Apple TV series ‚ÄúThe Savant‚Äù may be on hold, but her latest movie, out in February, is explosive enough to cause a new controversy on its own.

Comfort-cinema-opposed Mexican filmmaker Michel Franco brushed against hope and tenderness with his 2023 dementia-added love story ‚ÄúMemory,‚Äù but he's back in a pissed-off minor key over the state of the world ‚Äî and especially the toxic codependence between the U.S. and his home country ‚Äî in ‚ÄúDreams.‚Äù 

Remember the strikes of 2023? How quaint. Back then, Franco shot his ninth feature on location in the San Francisco Bay Area, courtesy of an interim waiver, and with ‚ÄúMemory‚Äù star Jessica Chastain, newcomer Isaac Hern√°ndez, and Rupert Friend in the cast. It went on to premiere at the 2025 Berlin Film Festival, unfortunately winning no awards from Todd Haynes' jury, and finally secured distribution from Greenwich Entertainment earlier this year. Watch the trailer below.

 








Related Stories Alejandro G. I√±√°rritu's Tom Cruise Movie Officially Titled ‚ÄòDigger,' Reveals First Look Teaser Jafar Panahi and Abbas Kiarostami Retrospective Set for IFC Center 

In ‚ÄúDreams,‚Äù Chastain plays a wealthy San Francisco arts patron whose life has been coddled and conflict-free, thanks to her powerful father. With a special interest in the ballet, she falls for a much-younger rising dancer (Hern√°ndez) while on a ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù trip to Mexico City, and he winds up illegally crossing the border through terrible circumstances to get to her. What could go wrong? It's an erotic, disturbing romance ‚Äî in other words, career-characteristic work from the director of sibling incest thriller ‚ÄúDaniel and Ana.‚Äù

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






As I wrote in my review out of Berlin, this film is ‚Äúan addictive and destructive love story as sharply wrought as the movie's grander political concerns‚Ä¶ There's not a lot of hope in ‚ÄòDreams,' and for that, it's a movie of our times and one that maybe can only exist because of them. It's about how the falsity of the American dream (a dream that is immigrants, after all) propels Mexican people to make the illegal dangerous crossing at all, and about how the U.S. and Mexico need each other in all ways.‚Äù

I also spoke to Franco and Chastain out of that festival, where Franco said, ‚ÄúI don't need to be liked as a filmmaker, for people to think, ‚ÄòOh, he's a good person.' I have no trouble about that. I am more interested in representing life. What's going on between the two countries and what Mexicans and immigrants are living in the States on a daily basis is much more dramatic than even what we portrayed [in ‚ÄòDreams']. So I wasn't shy about that. The main thing is it's true love. That's what makes it work, that they are in love, and that's why it's tragic.‚Äù

The movie arrives in theaters on February 27, 2026. Watch the trailer below.

Title: To Lure Director Frank Darabont Out of Retirement, Only a Personal Favorite Like ‚ÄòStranger Things' Would Do
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

For years, Frank Darabont was one of the most in-demand directors in Hollywood. While his career started with writing B-movie fare like ‚ÄúA Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors‚Äù and 1988's ‚ÄúThe Blob,‚Äù his breakthrough was in 1994 with the poignant Stephen King adaptation ‚ÄúThe Shawshank Redemption,‚Äù which he wrote and directed. The slow-burn success of that film, which bombed in theaters but has since become recognized as one of the greatest movies of all time, led to another Academy Award-nominated prison-based Stephen King drama, ‚ÄúThe Green Mile,‚Äù the slightly less lauded ‚ÄúThe Majestic,‚Äù and in 2007 a melding of his auteur chops and B-movie origins with yet another King adaptation, ‚ÄúThe Mist.‚Äù

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòWaiting for Godot' Breakout Michael Patrick Thornton on Keanu Reeves, What Happened to ‚ÄòThe Savant,' and Sian Heder's Next Film Amy Madigan on Playing Aunt Gladys in ‚ÄòWeapons,' Doing Stunts for the Film's Shocking Finale, and the Warner Bros. Sale 

Darabont probably could have kept trucking along with movies (and King adaptations), but instead he turned his sights on another horror adaptation, developing ‚ÄúThe Walking Dead‚Äù for AMC and building it into a massive hit‚Ä¶ At least before he was fired due to fights over what was later reported to be massive proposed budget cuts for the second season by the cable network. 

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






Darabont went on to create ‚ÄúMob City‚Äù for TNT in 2013, but that was canceled after one season. Following that, Darabont worked as a script doctor on 2014's ‚ÄúGodzilla,‚Äù and wrote a draft of, and was planning on directing, the ‚ÄúSnow White & The Huntsman‚Äù sequel ‚ÄúThe Huntsman: Winter's War,‚Äù until that seemingly fell apart due to the classic creative differences.

Since then? Darabont has been happily retired. Until now.

A few years back, the Duffer brothers, creators of the massive Netflix hit ‚ÄúStranger Things,‚Äù had lunch with Darabont, where the director expressed his fandom for the show ‚Äî he and his wife had already watched the first four seasons four or five times ‚Äî and the Duffers expressed their fandom back. But then they called him and invited him to direct an episode in the final season of the series. And he said yes.

That fifth episode, titled ‚ÄúShock Jock,‚Äù which will premiere on Netflix on Christmas Day (December 25), ended up becoming a double hit for Darabont when director Dan Trachtenberg had to drop out of directing the third episode, due to conflicts with the schedule for ‚ÄúPredator: Badlands.‚Äù While the Duffers floated moving Darabont to Episode 3, he told IndieWire he had another suggestion: ‚ÄúWhat if I do both?‚Äù

 










So 12 years after last sitting in the directing chair for ‚ÄúMob City,‚Äù Darabont is back for not one, but two episodes of ‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù Season 5. The first, titled ‚ÄúThe Turnbow Trap,‚Äù premiered as part of ‚ÄúVolume 1‚Äù on Thanksgiving Eve, and featured a ‚ÄúHome Alone‚Äù-style battle against a Demogorgon, as well as an iconic scene featuring Erica Sinclair (Priah Ferguson) drugging the entire Turnbow family with laced pie in order to save them from the villainous Vecna/Henry Creel (Jamie Campbell Bower).

As for ‚ÄúShock Jock,‚Äù as you might expect, the whole production is tight-lipped on the content, though Russ Duffer recently posted on Instagram that, ‚Äú‚ÄòShock Jock' picks up moments after the end of ‚ÄòSorcerer.' Frank Darabont is back, but he flexes very different muscles on this one than he did on ‚ÄòTurnbow Trap'‚Äî it's far darker, and far scarier.‚Äù

It also includes an Easter egg for something earlier in Darabont's career, as he revealed to IndieWire (given that the season takes place in 1987 and ‚ÄúNightmare on Elm Street 3‚Äù came out in 1987, you can likely venture a guess as to what that might be), and a chance to work more with the complicated baddie Henry Creel, who only briefly appears in ‚ÄúThe Turnbow Trap.‚Äù

 










To find out more from Darabont about why he came back to directing, what it would take for him to continue past ‚ÄúStranger Things,‚Äù and a bit of a correction about an oft-reported story on his history with Stephen King and ‚ÄúThe Dark Tower,‚Äù read on.

The following interview has been edited and condensed for clarity and length.

IndieWire: I was reading that the Duffers surprise-asked you to direct an episode, and that's what brought you out of retirement. Has nobody ever asked before?

Frank Darabont: [Laughs] Yeah, it was a surprise. I had been approached on a number of things through the years. But listen, after 30 years of being a workaholic machine in Hollywood, it's always easy to say no to pretty much everything. But when the Duffers offered, I was such a fan of the show that I actually had to say yes, and talked it over with my wife, and she said ‚Äî because we both love the show so much ‚Äî said, ‚ÄúYeah, this will be great.‚Äù 

It was initially going to be one episode, Episode 5. And then the director they had for Episode 3 had to drop out because of scheduling things, because of the strike. So they said, ‚ÄúHey, do you mind if we move you to Episode 3 instead?‚Äù And I said, ‚ÄúWhat if I do both?‚Äù That got me into six months in Atlanta, and I got to play pretty deeply in their sandbox.

 










This is just me intuiting from the outside, but it seems like TV led to some of your more frustrating experiences. Did you have any hesitation returning to TV, versus movies?

No, no. Not at all. Because in this situation, I'm a director for hire on a show that I love. I know they're going to give me excellent material, which they did. I had no battles to fight with a network or anything like that. I just had to show up and do the gig, which was very welcome. And I certainly trusted the Duffers to maintain their vision of the show that, God knows they've done four superb seasons so far. So I had no hesitation on that at all. 

What I said to them from the very start was: this is not my movie. This is your show. It's not a Frank Darabont [show]. This is your show. I just want to come and do a really good job, an incredible job, of directing what you want. Once you actually remove all the other stuff from ‚Äî that weight from your shoulders of having to be the authority of the show, it actually winds up being kind of a fun job. I loved it.

I was reviewing a lot of your work leading up to this interview, and you have this really masterful control of the camera, and I imagine a lot of that is going on behind the scenes as well. Given that it sounds like you really kind of let go for ‚ÄúStranger Things,‚Äù is that something you wish maybe you had done earlier in your career? Or is it something you're interested in doing going forward?
 










I actually was in that situation some years ago, because there was‚Äî oh, gosh, I can't remember exactly what year this was. You could probably look it up. [Note: It was 2007.] But Shawn Ryan heard that I was a big fan of ‚ÄúThe Shield.‚Äù His casting director, Deb Aquila, was my casting director on ‚ÄúShawshank‚Äù and on a whole lot of things, and she had mentioned how much I love the show, so I was invited to direct an episode of ‚ÄúThe Shield‚Äù as well, and that was a total shift of style, of approach. They had such brilliant camera operators. Billy Gerhardt and Richard Cantu and fantastic cinematographers, Rohn Schmidt, and it was all improvised camera work, all handheld, very documentary style. The approach was the polar opposite of everything I had done to that point. And that was very liberating. It just gave me another set of tools [in the] toolbox.

So coming to ‚ÄúStranger Things,‚Äù I was so familiar with the show, I watched all four seasons with my wife. I think we'd seen those four seasons about four or five times before this invitation arrived to come direct, because we just loved it so much. We just kept watching it. I felt like I was pretty familiar with the style. Plus, of course, you have a tremendous asset and resource in the Duffers themselves, who were open to having me ask them a lot of questions about what they wanted and how they wanted it done. And a tremendous resource in the crew that you're working with, which, by the way, was absolutely superb. What a crew. My goodness, I could go on and on about the camera operators and the grip and the lighting, the electricians, even the costuming. I mean, every department was AAA. A lot of them had been with the show for a while, some even from the start, like Amy [Parris], the costume maven there, she'd been with them from Season 1.

 










I had so many people that I could rely on to help guide the process. I had a great DP and a great AD, and those are the two positions that you're most collaborating with on a daily basis. And I was a little bit nervous, because usually, as a director, you're picking those people. I had them assigned to me. Happily, it turned out that I couldn't have picked better if I had picked. Brett Jutkiewicz and Lisa Rowe, my DP and my AD, were just amazing. Amazing colleagues, collaborators and whatever. There weren't any problems on the set that we couldn't figure out. It was a very smooth process and helped along by an amazing cast as well.

I'm going to ask you about some specifics in a second, but I'm really curious about watching ‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù four or five times.

Oh, it's excessive. It's absolutely excessive. Yeah, I know. There are occasionally those shows where you just‚Äî and they are occasional. There's a reason ‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù is the success that it is because people are just hooked in it. There's so many things to discover on a repeat viewing, along the way. Yeah, we were just kind of obsessed fans.

Your work is often characterized by whether people can find hope and connection in impossible places or fantastical circumstances. Is that what drew you to the show, or was it something else?
 










Well, that's a great strength of the show. It's a cornerstone of why it has such a devoted following. Because it really does have a moral compass. This thing, you have a found family ‚Äî some actual family ‚Äî this group of people have been brought together by these circumstances, and they are always trying to do the right thing. There's tremendous positivity in that group. There's tremendous loyalty. They will sacrifice for one another. And you don't see that kind of heart in a lot of our entertainment. There's a lot of dour‚Ä¶ There's a lot of greed.

Basically, I can't watch another thing about some psycho killer. That's the positivity of it. It's very much as it is with tone, as it is with period, is very much a throwback to an earlier kind of storytelling. That's why people relate to it. To Steveen Spielberg's work and to Stephen King's work, because those storytellers always had a lot of heart and a lot of positivity in their stories, no matter how dire circumstances would get. You had those people wanting to do the right thing and being protective of one another. That's really the heart of the show, and that's why we loved it so much.

Last night, I rewatched ‚ÄúThe Mist‚Äù and then immediately flipped over to rewatching ‚ÄúThe Turnbow Trap,‚Äù and I was really struck by the leap in special effects. The special effects are really good in ‚ÄúThe Mist,‚Äù the creatures are great. But then you open up on the scene of Hopper chopping open the wall on ‚ÄúStranger Things.‚Äù For you, behind the scenes and from the technical perspective, what was that leap like? Coming into ‚ÄúStranger Things,‚Äù what did you have to learn? What did you have to embrace?
 










Well, one of the great strengths of the show is the fact that Netflix has really supported it. They had real budgets to work with. Whereas on ‚ÄúThe Mist,‚Äù we were kind of in the bargain basement end of things in terms of production. Not to disparage that, because I really loved working with those constraints, etc, and I thought that CafeFX did a great job for me. Really terrific. Doing stuff for much less than someplace else would have charged.

But going into this, I knew they were going to have ILM and WƒìtƒÅ doing their effects work. That gives you a real comfort zone. All you have to do is, thank god we had Sean Ames and Betsy [Paterson]‚Ä¶ They were our liaisons with the effects houses, and they were always on the set. So again, great support for a director. And always turn to them and say, ‚ÄúOK, if we do it this way, is it going to give the effects people what they need?‚Äù Or ‚ÄúHow do we adjust this to make it work better for that end of things?‚Äù And they would always give me a great answer, or at least a thumbs up and say, ‚ÄúYeah, what you're doing is going to work fine.‚Äù I knew that the effects work would be world class, because if you got ILM and WƒìtƒÅ, they're going to be.

It was really, really great fun for me to see the episode aired, because I had seen only temp effects, at best. When I was doing my director's cut, I'd only really seen temp effects so to see the finished thing, all properly put together, and the little eyes dotted and T's crossed, was really thrilling. When the Demogorgon falls into the basement and all that stuff, it's like, wow. It's really, really cool. Of course, you're on the set with, say, Finn [Wolfhard], right? He's got this big thing. I'm sure this is how Ray Harryhausen had to do it back in the day. ‚ÄúNow, just pretend he's there and jab at him and take a swing.‚Äù And he's acting his heart out to thin air. And by the time the effects people do their magic, it looks fantastic.

 










I love it. I love that. I love pulling the rabbit out of the hat, no matter what scale that is. It's one of the things I love about filmmaking, as simple as an editing trick, or somebody walks into a building on some location somewhere, and then walks into a different door months later on a set and that simple cut makes it look like the same place. Even that has always tickled me about what we do. I really dig it.

My favorite scene in the first four episodes is Erica serving pie to the Turnbow family. And the reason I love that is it turns on so many dimes. It goes from comedy to horror to drama‚Ä¶ So as a director, when you're crafting something like that, how do you make sure you're modulating it so it has the proper arc to the scene?

Oh, golly. Wow. I figured the comedy of it would speak for itself. I just wanted the characters to be, given the material, as real as they could be. And I knew I had a great little thing up my sleeve with the actor, who plays the dad, Mr. Turnbow [Gray Hawks], when he's starting to get a little woozy. I knew that one camera trick that we had where you put the camera on the actor and it looks really weird was gonna really help sell the whole thing.

You're just in there with a group of people trying to make it as consistent in tone as possible. That's really the thing. And I knew that was going to be one of those scenes where the tone swings for the fences a little bit. I remember asking the Duffers during one of our me asking questions sessions, ‚Äúokay, do you actually really want to see the needle going into the neck? Do you really want Erica to actually do that? Or can we suggest it more?‚Äù And they said, ‚ÄúNo, no, go for it. Go for it. Just absolutely don't think twice. Just make it as shocking as you can.‚Äù I went, ‚ÄúOK, here we go.‚Äù

 










And by the way, that young actress [Caroline Elle Abrams], she gave me the best 1980s horror movie scream. I was so delighted with her scream. I actually had to shorten it a little bit in the cut, she really stretched it out. But she really sold that moment, that beat for us.

Of all the characters on the show, Henry Creel, in a weird way ‚Äî I know you don't deal with him too much in the third episode ‚Äî seems right in your wheelhouse. Do you see any connection between him and, say, Percy from ‚ÄúThe Green Mile,‚Äù or Mother Carmody from ‚ÄúThe Mist‚Äù? Do you have any sympathy for him? Those characters always have this essential human flaw that makes you think, if they just tweaked it a little bit, maybe they'd be a little bit better.

Yeah, Henry's really interesting. He's not even a sociopath anymore. He's gone into some other realm of crazy. I'm not going to give away anything, but I did get to work with that wonderful actor, Jamie [Campbell Bower], more in the fifth episode, which was a real treat for me. We do explore him a bit more in the second half, and he's really so driven by this morbid level of hatred for the world, that is what drives him, with Jamie, who's such an accomplished actor, playing against that almost. We saw it in the third episode. This sort of gentle approach that he's used, but it's so creepy and calculating‚Ä¶ This gentle, friendly thing. It was a brilliant stroke on the Duffers' part, on the writers part, to approach him from that direction, and surprise the audience, surprise the characters in the show as well.

 










About a year ago, when the gig was first announced, you said you missed working with creative people, but weren't sure about returning to directing again beyond ‚ÄúStranger Things.‚Äù Has that changed at all now that you've seen the reception to, at least the first episode?

You know, I actually love being retired. I grow roses. They look great. I'm trying to get better at doing watercolors, and I'm trying to learn the guitar, which I kind of suck at still, but I'm trying‚Ä¶ My Hollywood years were like nine years of trying and then followed by almost 30 years of doing and those years went by in such a blur, I am a bit reluctant. But then again, on the other hand, when you have a great experience like I had, on ‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù with that cast, with that crew, it does kind of make you wonder if you want to get back in the saddle again.

But it would have to be‚Ä¶ Well, let me put it this way. My best experience directing was for Castle Rock because they were just such a filmmaker-friendly place. They really supported you instead of fought you. If they made a suggestion, it wasn't with a baseball bat in their hands ready to beat you over the head. It was just a suggestion that you could take or leave. If every place was like that, then life would be better. I had a great experience working for Michael Wright at TNT, for ‚ÄúMob City.‚Äù It was the closest thing I'd felt to my Castle Rock days.

 










I just don't want to fight any battles, and I don't want to have a lack of goodwill at the top, because that lack of goodwill rolls downhill. And so if it's a friendly place where they're going to trust the filmmaker, yeah, I'd certainly consider it. I'm too old to fight any battles anymore. I'm too old to get swept out with the trash at their convenience.

This is almost the opposite of what you're saying, but rewatching ‚ÄúThe Mist,‚Äù I had forgotten it opens with that painting of Roland from ‚ÄúThe Dark Tower.‚Äù I know you were turned down by Stephen King way back in the day for it, but I feel like you have to have a take for ‚ÄúThe Dark Tower‚Äù somewhere.

Actually, I can correct that: I actually turned Steve down. He called me once, and it's not the only time he ever called me, but he called me once and asked me if I was interested in taking on ‚ÄúThe Dark Tower.‚Äù I was very flattered and very honored that he asked me. But man, so much of that story is so internalized. It's so in the heads of the characters, and it's this massive, endless story as well. I thought, oh my god, this could be the next 10 years of my life and miss the mark, because it is a diabolically difficult thing to adapt. And at that point, I was just exhausted anyway. 

 










And I said, ‚ÄúSteve, I love you‚Ä¶ Thank you for asking, but I gotta not do this.‚Äù I would have frozen in place if I had. He was very, very kind about that and then moved on with it. A couple of years later, when we were having a conversation, I said, ‚ÄúSo wait, what's going on with ‚ÄòThe Dark Tower'? I don't know, I might reconsider that.‚Äù He said, ‚ÄúOh, no, it's with somebody else by now.‚Äù So you know, that may be where the he turned me down thing comes from. 

You know, who knows? These were just honestly idle conversations that occur on occasion between me and Steve King, one of the world's greatest people. I really owe him so much. You can imagine, my whole directing career, I owe to Steve King.

I saw another interview where you said there was an Easter egg to some of your earlier work in the episode. And I kept an eye out, but I feel like I missed it. I was looking if there was, like, a clip from ‚ÄúThe Woman in the Room,‚Äù or ‚ÄúNightmare on Elm Street 3‚Äù or something.

Yeah, the Easter egg actually is in Episode 5. And when you see it, you'll ‚Äî believe me ‚Äî you'll know it. It is one of my early gigs, and it was something wonderfully suggested by the Duffer brothers, who were big fans of that particular film. It's fun, and it gave me a little opportunity to honor another friend of mine from way back in the day, we worked together. So you'll see it. When you see it, you'll know.

 










‚ÄúStranger Things‚Äù Season 5, Volume 1 is now streaming on Netflix. Volume 2 premieres December 25 and Volume 3 (‚ÄúThe Finale‚Äù) premieres December 31.

Title: Jafar Panahi and Abbas Kiarostami Retrospective Set for IFC Center
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

In January, New York's IFC Center will host a timely new retrospective, ‚ÄúPanahi & Kiarostami: Two Masters,‚Äù as IndieWire announces exclusively. Running from January 2‚Äì8, 2026, the 18-film program will celebrate the interconnected work of acclaimed Iranian filmmakers Jafar Panahi and Abbas Kiarostami. 

The retrospective comes amid a surge for Panahi, following the release of his recent feature ‚ÄúIt Was Just an Accident,‚Äù which has just been shortlisted for a Best International Feature Oscar. After decades of crafting subversively political films that have made him an enemy of the Iranian government, Panahi won this year's Palme d'Or for his dark-comedy-laced thriller about a group of former detainees debating the fate of the man they believe to be their prison tormentor. And while the award and the many accolades that followed contributed to Panahi once again being targeted by his country's regime, it also brought renewed attention to his stunning body of work ‚Äî including his directorial debut, 1995's ‚ÄúThe White Balloon,‚Äù which was written by Kiarostami.  

 








Related Stories Alejandro G. I√±√°rritu's Tom Cruise Movie Officially Titled ‚ÄòDigger,' Reveals First Look Teaser At the ‚ÄòMarty Supreme' New York Premiere, Everyone from Anna Wintour to Zohran Mamdani Toasted the Big Apple ‚Äî and Timoth√©e Chalamet 

The mini-festival, conceptualized and programmed by the critic Godfrey Cheshire, offers New York audiences a chance to experience that body of work, alongside Kiarostami's influential films, on the big screen. 

 










‚ÄúJafar Panahi, who for 17 years has been imprisoned and harassed by the Iranian government, and prevented from seeing his films with any audience, is now one of the world's preeminent filmmakers and seems headed for Oscar nominations,‚Äù Cheshire said in a statement. ‚ÄúIn spite of all the attention given to ‚ÄòIt Was Just an Accident,' many audiences don't know how long and distinguished his career has been. Our festival ‚ÄòPanahi & Kiarostami: Two Masters' is meant to rectify that by presenting nine of his previous features, including such masterworks as ‚ÄòThe White Balloon,' ‚ÄòThis Is Not a Film,' and ‚ÄòNo Bears' ‚Ä¶ alongside nine features by his mentor, the great Abbas Kiarostami.‚Äù 

Among the Kiarostami titles featured in the program are ‚ÄúThrough the Olive Trees‚Äù ‚Äî which will be accompanied by a Q&A with Panahi, who served as an assistant on the film ‚Äî and the Palme d'Or-winning ‚ÄúTaste of Cherry.‚Äù The full list of films featured in ‚ÄúPanahi & Kiarostami: Two Masters‚Äù is below.  Head to IFC Center's website for more information.

Friday, January 2 10:35 a.m. ‚ÄúAnd Life Goes On‚Äù (Abbas Kiarostami, 1992) 12:40 p.m. ‚ÄúOffside‚Äù (Jafar Panahi, 2006) ‚Äì 35mm print 2:50 p.m. ‚ÄúClose-Up‚Äù (Kiarostami, 1990) 5:05 p.m. ‚Äú3 Faces‚Äù (Panahi, 2018) 7:35 p.m. ‚ÄúThe White Balloon‚Äù (Panahi, 1995) ‚Äì 35mm print 9:45 p.m. ‚ÄúWhere Is the Friend's House‚Äù (Kiarostami, 1987) 

 










Saturday, January 3 10:35 a.m. ‚ÄúClose-Up‚Äù 12:45 p.m. ‚Äú3 Faces‚Äù 3:00 p.m. ‚ÄúThe White Balloon‚Äù ‚Äì 35mm print 5:05 p.m. ‚ÄúWhere Is the Friend's House‚Äù 7:10 p.m. ‚ÄúThe Wind Will Carry Us‚Äù (Kiarostami, 1999) 9:50 p.m. ‚ÄúNo Bears‚Äù (Panahi, 2022) 

Sunday, January 4 11:30 a.m. ‚ÄúThrough the Olive Trees‚Äù (Kiarostami, 1994) *1:15 p.m. Panel: ‚ÄúPanahi & Kiarostami‚Äù 2:45 p.m. ‚ÄúTaste of Cherry‚Äù (Kiarostami, 1997) 5:05 p.m. ‚ÄúThe Circle‚Äù (Panahi, 2000) 7:20 p.m. ‚ÄúOffside‚Äù ‚Äì 35mm print 9:35 p.m. ‚ÄúAnd Life Goes On‚Äù 

Monday, January 5 12:30 p.m. ‚ÄúClosed Curtain‚Äù (Panahi, 2013) 2:45 p.m. ‚ÄúTen‚Äù (Kiarostami, 2002) 4:35 p.m. ‚ÄúTaxi‚Äù (Panahi, 2015) 6:00 p.m. ‚ÄúThrough the Olive Trees‚Äù ‚Äì post-screening Q&A with Jafar Panahi, moderated by Godfrey Cheshire 8:35 p.m. ‚ÄúThis Is Not a Film‚Äù (Panahi, 2011) ‚Äì extended intro by Jafar Panahi 

Tuesday, January 6 10:40 a.m. ‚ÄúTaste of Cherry‚Äù 12:45 p.m. ‚ÄúThe Circle‚Äù 2:55 p.m. ‚ÄúTen‚Äù 5:10 p.m. ‚ÄúTaxi‚Äù 7:15 p.m. ‚ÄúCrimson Gold‚Äù (Panahi, 2003) 9:30 p.m. ‚ÄúThe Traveler‚Äù (Kiarostami, 1974) 

 










Wednesday, January 7 10:35 a.m. ‚ÄúCrimson Gold‚Äù 12:35 p.m. ‚ÄúThe Traveler‚Äù2:25 p.m. ‚ÄúThe Wind Will Carry Us‚Äù5:00 p.m. ‚ÄúNo Bears‚Äù7:35 p.m. ‚ÄúTen‚Äù9:45 p.m. ‚ÄúTaxi‚Äù

Thursday, January 8 10:40 a.m. ‚ÄúThrough the Olive Trees‚Äù12:40 p.m. ‚ÄúThis Is Not a Film‚Äù2:25 p.m. ‚ÄúClose-Up‚Äù4:40 p.m. ‚Äú3 Faces‚Äù7:00 p.m. ‚ÄúCertified Copy‚Äù (Kiarostami, 2010) 9:25 p.m. ‚ÄúClosed Curtain‚Äù

Title: The Flaming Lips' Steven Drozd Says He's No Longer in Band
Description:
Steven Drozd‚Äîthe Flaming Lips' longtime guitarist, multi-instrumentalist, and primary songwriter alongside Wayne Coyne‚Äîis no longer in the band, according to a since-deleted post Drozd made online. When replying to a fan on Threads who asked if he was ‚Äúofficially done with the FLips,‚Äù the musician replied, ‚ÄúThey're done with me ‚Äì but we're not talking about it. So yes I'm moving on. Just keep it to yourself for now. OK?‚Äù

Pitchfork has reached out to a representative of the Flaming Lips for comment.

Drozd joined the Flaming Lips in 1991 and has been a key member of the experimental psych-rock group ever since. Although he and Coyne have formed several side projects together in the past, Drozd has never parted ways with or taken a break from the band in those 34 years.

As Consequence points out, fans started speculating about Drozd's status in the Flaming Lips several months ago when they noticed he was absent from their concerts. During the band's recent string of shows, AJ Slaughter was covering Drozd's parts in his place.

Read about the Flaming Lips' 1999 LP The Soft Bulletin in ‚ÄúThe 150 Best Albums of the 1990s.‚Äù

Title: YouTube Ditches the Billboard Charts
Description:
Songs streamed on YouTube will no longer count towards the Billboard charts, the platform announced in a blog yesterday (December 17). The change will take effect on January 16, 2026, according to Lyor Cohen, YouTube's global head of music. Cohen blamed a long-running dispute over Billboard's decision to weight subscriber streams more favorably than ad-supported streams in its chart tallies.

YouTube is threatening to pull its data despite a recent rule change that suggests a compromise on the issue: This week, Billboard announced it would more generously weight ad-supported, on-demand streams in comparison to their subscriber counterparts. That shift equates a stream by a YouTube or Spotify subscriber to two and a half streams by a non-subscriber. Before that, the ratio was 3:1, meaning a free stream was worth even less. But Cohen maintains this an ‚Äúoutdated formula‚Äù that ‚Äúignores the massive engagement from fans who don't have a subscription.‚Äù He notes that streaming makes up 84 percent of U.S. recorded music revenue and suggests that YouTube was pursuing a 1:1 ratio in streaming counts.

Why YouTube is so determined to bump up free streams is not entirely clear. Cohen argues that artists' work on fan-engagement on the platform is ‚Äúbeing undervalued‚Äù by Billboard, hinting he believes a more generous chart contribution would drive activity on the platform. Also unclear is whether the disagreement pertains only to the ratio of subscriber to non-subscriber streams, or whether YouTube also disputes what Billboard counts as an on-demand stream. On YouTube, as on Spotify, some autoplays that follow an active song selection may be excluded from chart tallies. Pitchfork has emailed representatives for YouTube for further comment.

A Billboard spokesperson said in a statement, ‚ÄúThere are so many ways a fan can support an artist they love, and each has a specific place in the music ecosystem. Billboard strives to measure that activity appropriately; balanced by various factors including consumer access, revenue analysis, data validation and industry guidance. It is our hope that YouTube reconsiders and joins Billboard in recognizing the reach and popularity of artists on all music platforms and in celebrating their achievements though the power of fans and how they interact with the music that they love.‚Äù

Title: Perry Farrell Apologizes to Jane's Addiction (Again)
Description:
In September of last year, Jane's Addiction frontman Perry Farrell attacked guitarist Dave Navarro onstage during a concert in Boston. The band cut short the show and cancelled the remaining dates of a planned reunion tour of North America. At the time, Farrell issued an apology and all four members said they ‚Äúhad made the difficult decision to take some time away as a group.‚Äù Now, he and Jane's Addiction have shared additional statements addressing the incident and confirming his departure from the band. Read both in full below.

‚ÄúJane's Addiction has been at the center of my life for decades,‚Äù Farrell wrote in a joint Instagram post with the band. ‚ÄúThe band, the songs, the patrons and the impact that we've had on music and culture mean more to me than any words I could ever possibly write down. My aim has always been to give our audience the best possible show, something real, honest and positive. In Boston, we fell short of that, and I'm truly sorry to everyone who was impacted.‚Äù

In their own post, the remaining members of Jane's Addiction‚ÄîNavarro, bassist Eric Avery, and drummer Stephen Perkins‚Äîshared, ‚Äúwe unilaterally determined it would be best to not continue the tour and made inaccurate statements about Perry's mental health which we regret.‚Äù They added, ‚ÄúWe now look forward to the future as we embark on our separate musical and creative endeavors.‚Äù

Jane's Addiction's original lineup reunited in 2024 with a new song, ‚ÄúImminent Redemption.‚Äù A second new song, ‚ÄúTrue Love,‚Äù arrived just a couple of days after the Boston incident. Earlier this year, Navarro, Avery, and Perkins sued Farrell, claiming a loss of $10 million in potential earnings from the cancelled reunion shows and a new album that was reportedly never completed. Farrell then countersued, alleging that his bandmates engaged in a ‚Äúyears-long bullying campaign‚Äù against him. Pitchfork has reached out for representatives for Jane's Addiction to confirm whether the suits will continue.

Revisit the Sunday Review of Jane's Addiction's 1988 album Nothing's Shocking.

Perry Farrell:

To everyone in Boston, and around the world.

I'd like to address what happened on stage last year. I've reflected on it and know I didn't handle myself the way I should have. I apologize to our patrons and my bandmates for losing my temper and for disrupting the show.

Jane's Addiction has been at the center of my life for decades.

The band, the songs, the patrons and the impact that we've had on music and culture mean more to me than any words I could ever possibly write down.

My aim has always been to give our audience the best possible show, something real, honest and positive. In Boston, we fell short of that, and I'm truly sorry to everyone who was impacted.

From the bottom of my heart, I want to thank each and every one of you for your continued love and support.

Jane's Addiction:

We would like to clarify the events surrounding the cancellation of the tour after the show in Boston in September 2024.

After that show, without notice to Perry, we unilaterally determined it would be best to not continue the tour and made inaccurate statements about Perry's mental health which we regret.

Today we are here to announce that we have come together one last time to resolve our differences, so that the legacy of Jane's Addiction will remain the work the four of us created together.

We now look forward to the future as we embark on our separate musical and creative endeavors. Jane's Addiction will forever live in our hearts. We are proud of the music we created together.

You, the fans, are our lifeblood, and we will always appreciate you.
